Award.AwardTitle: Second Workshop on Coreference Resolution Beyond OntoNotes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award aims to subsidize travel, workshop and housing expenses of selected students participating in the Second Workshop on Coreference Resolution Beyond OntoNotes (CORBON 2017), which will be held on April 4, 2017, immediately preceding the EACL 2017 conference in Valencia, Spain.
Only students from U.S. universities who participate in CORBON 2017 as co-authors and/or presenters of papers accepted to the workshop will be considered for the travel awards. Preference will be given to (1) students who are in the final year of their Ph.D. where making long-term collegial connections is valuable and (2) any financially needy students.

Following the successes of CORBON 2016, the first of this series of workshops on coreference resolution, CORBON 2017 continues to encourage work on under-investigated coreference resolution tasks as well as coreference resolution in less-studied languages. CORBON 2017 will have two major innovations: a shared task on entity coreference resolution in a surprise language and a panel discussing the interplay of referential and discourse relations in text. The travel awards supported by this project will enable selected students to participate in this exciting workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported student travel to the Second Workshop on Coreference Resolution Beyond OntoNotes (CORBON 2017, held in conjunction with the EACL 2017 conference in Valencia, Spain on April 4, 2017), as well as its two successors, the First Workshop on Computational Models of Reference, Anaphora and Coreference (CRAC 2018, held in conjunction with the NAACL HLT 2018 conference in New Orleans, LA on June 6, 2018) and the Second Workshop on Computational Models of Reference, Anaphora and Coreference (CRAC 2019, held in conjunction with the NAACL HLT 2019 conference in Minneapolis, MN on June 7, 2019). EACL and NAACL HLT are two of the premiere conferences on natural language processing (NLP), a subfield of artificial intelligence that is concerned with the study of human languages from a computational perspective.

This workshop series started in 2016, with the goal of providing a common forum for NLP researchers to meet and discuss the future directions for coreference resolution research. Coreference resolution, the task of determining which words/phrases in a text document refer to the same real-world entity or event, is generally considered one of the most challenging problems in NLP. The workshop was originally organized under the name CORBON (Coreference Resolution Beyond OntoNotes), but it was changed to CRAC (the present name) in 2018 when its focus was broadened to cover all cases of computational modeling of reference, anaphora, and coreference. Currently, CRAC is the only venue for coreference researchers to meet and discuss their ideas and vision for coreference research outside the mainstream NLP conferences.

Each workshop was organized as a one-day event composed of one or more invited talks given by renowned researchers on coreference resolution, oral presentations of accepted papers, a shared task session containing presentations of systems designed for a particular task challenge we presented to the coreference community, as well as a poster session where authors of accepted papers showcased their research via posters. In each session, there was ample time for the participants to engage in discussion with the speakers and the presenters. 

Students are less likely than faculty to be able to pay the expenses associated with workshop attendance. This is especially true for participants who will benefit the most from the workshop (i.e., students who are not members of established research groups). As a means of encouraging young and upcoming computational linguists interested in coreference resolution, this award program seems to be an inexpensive and yet effective method. As a direct result of this award, four students were able to attend this workshop series. In particular, this award has helped to bring together a pool of researchers with the scientific and engineering knowledge of NLP, and provided a supportive environment for a new generation of coreference researchers in which they interacted with other researchers in the field, received critical feedback from them on their work, and in some cases established collaborations with them.
